title: Improving Customer Relationships Through Product Enhancements
author: Benjamiz

content: In a year marked by layoffs, restructuring, and customer unhappiness, our main goal was to improve our relationship with customers. Who had grown despondent with the lack of change in functionality of the platform, as we focused on the transition to enterprise software development. Our objective this year as a product team was to deliver a road map of highly requested and valuable features to regain customer support and trust in the product.
Identifying and Implementing a Key Feature: Version History
The Demand for Version History

Restoring past versions of content pages was a straightforward feature to add, and 'version history' was often requested. Initially, I was unsure of its value against other possible features. With only a few support logs [around 7 per quarter], the frequent feature requests highlighted a demand. I suspected users made changes they later wished to undo, finding it easier to redo the work than navigate support. User interviews confirmed this; when asked about reversing major changes, most had a story to share. Considering our goals and the feature's simplicity, we moved forward. As the development team worked on backend storage for versions, I looked into how users would find and revert to older versions.
Development and User Experience Design

To align with Jacob's Law and ensure familiarity and ease of use, I explored the common usability and layout patterns for version history in Google Docs, Office 365 (Word), and Figma. This was because our content page editors—either in-house learning designers or university staff—commonly used Google Docs and Microsoft Word. I included Figma in the analysis, anticipating that its status as a design tool meant it had a refined history function. This approach aimed to ensure the feature would meet user expectations, which would be shaped by their familiarity with similar features from other platforms. Finally, with the help of users, I looked at other online learning platforms’ attempts at version history.
Usability Concerns and Solutions
Discovery and Restoration Process

After analyzing these programs, I distilled the main themes and common usability patterns and shared these insights with the developers. Together, we brainstormed some layout ideas and developed rough sketches of the layout and where the feature would live. For ease of implementation, we settled for a full-screen modal.

I wasn't too concerned about this feature's usability, especially regarding finding and restoring versions given that this type of feature exists in so many other platforms and the design inspiration came from tools that our users use every day. After discussions with the lead developer, I ended up with two main usability worries.

The first was about how users would discover the feature, and the second was around user expectation of functionality behaviour. Though these seem straightforward, our platform's technical limitations meant we couldn't simplify the process in a way users might expect for this initial launch.
Finding the feature

The development team planned to change the content page as little as possible, so I went through various designs until we found one they were willing to implement. Then, I sought to validate this solution with users. We had access to in-house experts (our learning designers) for quick feedback. However, their deep familiarity with the system meant I had to remember that non-experts might interact with the platform differently.

I conducted interviews with both external and internal users focusing on whether they could easily find this feature. The responses varied, with some finding the feature without guidance and others struggling. I noticed variations in the time it took users to find the feature and their approaches, but overall, I found it acceptable for release. Once users located it, they agreed it was placed logically and found it clear. Since our platform lacks a feature to highlight and educate users on new updates, provided we made our release notes and support documents clear, accessible, and well-distributed, we would be able to minimise the risk of the feature being overlooked by users. I shared these insights and recommendations with the product manager and customer support lead.

In every test, once users found the history button, they easily navigated the workflow to revert to older versions. Our decision to limit history to the last 50 saves was generally well-received. I had concerns about users potentially spam-saving and losing earlier versions, but after a review, we found that pages were saved on average 20-25 times. So, setting the limit at 50 appeared to be a reasonable choice.
The concern was ensuring users' expectations matched the system's behaviour.
Finding the feature

Our pages contain three main types of content: basic text from the editor, videos, and iframed content. Our platform's unique selling point is our activity bank, crucial for student engagement. Effective learning experiences often involve a variety of learning modalities, including text, video, and interactive elements. Online, this typically means blending these formats. However, activities on our platform are implemented as iframes. While the history feature could track the presence and placement of activity, it couldn't capture the content within those iframes because it was external to the data saved by our text editor.

For the scope of this project, we would only be focusing on the text editor content. However, from my interviews, users valued access to activities as much as they did the rich text editor content. However, our support logs showed no requests to revert changes to activity content.

This seemed like a red herring to me. For users, activities and rich text content were perceived as part of the same thing, the content of the page. So it was reasonable to assume that they would ask for a page restore regardless of what it was they wanted to restore. However, it was unclear from the support logs if version restore requests were specifically about activities or the text content.

My conversations with users suggested that not including both in the version restore would likely disappoint users, as it would seem like an incomplete solution. I relayed these insights and concerns to the product manager, recommending clear communication at launch to manage expectations and prevent confusion.
Reflections on Project Management and Design Process
Collaboration and Feedback Loops

What I enjoyed about this project was my frequent interactions with the development team. They were working in sprints, but I got their feedback every couple of days. This allowed us to figure out what frontend features they could build, what might change based on user feedback, and what needed to stay fixed. This approach meant that by the time I was happy with the design, most of it was already coded, requiring only minor adjustments and styling.

The feature, by its nature, wasn't set to be revolutionary, given it offered functionality expected of any document editor. My recommendations for setting realistic expectations were overlooked, leading to dissatisfaction among our internal learning design team due to the absence of activities. I played a key role in mitigating the resulting conflict between them and the product team, by talking to both heads of departments getting their perspectives and relaying the other’s perspective.
Challenges and Lessons Learned

The main challenge was designing around the system’s technical debt with a focus on user needs rather than just what was technically easy, I first needed to understand the constraints of the system before I was able to test the user’s understanding of the feature and the actions it performed. My initial design may have been too ambitious, but regular feedback from developers and users helped refine it into a practical solution that balanced ease of implementation with user benefit.
Conclusion

Following a positive beta test, we proceeded with the launch, which was received favourably overall. The feature's success in enhancing customer satisfaction became evident in conversations involving our managing director, head of product, and our customers, indicating our efforts to strengthen customer relationships were effective. Additionally, my direct engagement with users and incorporating their feedback into the final product contributed significantly to this improvement.

I think given the low complexity and usability risk factors I did an adequate amount of testing what I should have done better at was ensuring I had input on the release strategy so that we built the right expectations up with our users and not create an environment for disappointment to grow.
